heisig_chinese_memo: To bribe someone, money is a necessary possession.
heisig_constituent: bribe, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, possess, by one‚Äôs side, moon, month, flesh, part of the body
heisig_story: To the left we have the primitive for a shellfish, and to the right the kanji we just learned for possess. Keep the connotation of the last frame for the word possess, and now expand your image of shells to include the ancient value they had as money (a usage that will come in very helpful later on). Now one who is possessed by shells is likely to abandon any higher principles to acquire more and more wealth. These are the easiest ones to bribe with a few extra shells.
koohiiStory1: To bribe someone, money is a necessary possession.
koohiiStory2: If you possess enough shellfish, you can bribe anyone.
jp_example_words: Ë≥Ñ„ÅÜ(„Åæ„Åã„Å™„ÅÜ): to give board to, to provide meals, to pay
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The more shellfish you have, the more you can bribe people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine bribing a bunch of yakuza and politicians with all the shellfish you have. Ohohoh, you'll never be caught!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Welp, the cops found out about your bribe, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "WHY („Çè„ÅÑ)?!
WaniKani_Reading_Info:
Yeah really, why? Why bribe people at all. You could have just been rolling in shellfish dough. Why risk everything?
And you counter with.
Why not?
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the shellfish (Ë≤ù) possesses (Êúâ) the bribe, and he's using it to provide for himself
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Shellfish can't be bribed with money so you'll have to possess it.
humanum_full_description_en:
From the " shell ", " have " sound. The original meaning is property. "Said Wen": "Bribery, money. Congbei, there is sound." "Er Ya. "Explanation": "Bribery, wealth." Xing Qingshu: "Bribery, wealth and name." Such as "Poetry. Wei Feng. Mogul: "Come with Erche, take me to bribe and move." "Huainanzi. Synopsis: "The world has not been determined, and the domestic has not been compiled. The king of Wu wanted to show the deeds of the king of Wen, so that Yi and Di each paid tribute with their bribes, but far away."

Ancient books often use " goods " and " bribery " together, such as "Book of Rites. "Monthly Order" "Bringing Goods", "Zuo Zhuan. "Eighteen Years of Wengong" "Break in Goods" etc. In fact, " goods " mostly refers to gold and jade, while " bribery " mostly refers to cloth. "Zhou Li. Heaven official. "Dazai" "Six refers to merchants, Fu currency bribery", Zheng Xuan's note: "Jin and jade refer to goods, cloth and silk refer to bribery." Therefore, the "Suo Wen" paragraph quotes "Zhou Li" Zheng's note after the comment: "Analysis of words. To put it bluntly, goods and bribes are said to be wealth."

The extension of " bribery " means giving away money. "Jade articles. Beibu": "Bibbling, giving money as gifts." Such as "Rituals. The Betrothal Gift: "The doctor bribed the use of beam spinning." Zheng Xuan's note: "bribery is a word for money." "Zuo Zhuan. "The Seventh Year of Wen Gong": "When he died, Xun Bo gave all his money and money to bribes to Qin, saying: "It is the same old man.""

" Bribery " was later extended to mean bribery or bribery, that is, using property to buy others. Such as "Hou Han Shu. "The Biography of Chen Wang": "If the law loses its balance and the official loses its own person, then there is a lack of kingship, and the theory that makes the world is that prison is caused by grievances, and lords are made by bribes." Pei Ju Biography ":" When discipline Mi vibration, Yuwen Shu, Yu Shiji Allusions bribe officials to move, only moments very dirty section without sound, the world rather call it. "See" bribe "," bribe . "
humanum_short_description_en: From the " shell ", " have " sound. The original meaning is property, and by extension it means donating property.

hu√¨
–≤–º. Ë¥ø
Radicals: Ë≤ù, Êúâ  (shellfish, have)
Meaning Mnemonic
The more shellfish you have, the more you can bribe people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood.
Imagine bribing a bunch of yakuza and politicians with all the shellfish you have. Ohohoh, you'll never be caught!
Reading Mnemonic
Welp, the cops found out about your bribe, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "WHY („Çè„ÅÑ)?!
Yeah really, why? Why bribe people at all. You could have just been rolling in shellfish dough. Why risk everything?
And you counter with.
Why not?
